title: 112_s3214
content: The "Today's Entrepreneurs are America's Mentors Act" or the "TEAM Act" defines terms like "Administration" and "small business concern" under the Small Business Act. It also establishes an Office of Entrepreneurial Education within the Small Business Administration. The "TEAM Act" establishes the Office of Entrepreneurial Education within the Administration to provide innovative entrepreneurial information and resources for prospective entrepreneurs and small business concerns. The Director of the Office manages online courses and publications for entrepreneurs. The Office of Entrepreneurial Education manages online courses, publications, and resources for entrepreneurs and small businesses. It also oversees youth entrepreneurship programs, including online resources and coordination with service providers. Additionally, it collaborates with nonprofit and private sector partners to share educational materials on money. The Office of Entrepreneurial Education manages resources for entrepreneurs and small businesses, including youth entrepreneurship programs and collaboration with partners to share financial education materials. Additionally, it provides assistance to individuals and foreign dignitaries interested in entrepreneurial issues. The Associate Administrator for Entrepreneurial Development will establish a program to provide grants to nonprofit organizations for technical assistance in developing entrepreneurship curricula and mentoring programs for primary and secondary schools. The Associate Administrator for Entrepreneurial Development will provide grants to nonprofit organizations for curricula and mentoring programs promoting entrepreneurship in schools. Nonprofit organizations must submit an application outlining project goals, partners involved, and any other required information. Within a year of receiving the grant, a report must be submitted to the Associate Administrator. The nonprofit organization receiving a grant must submit a report within a year detailing the individuals assisted, jobs created or saved, and any other required information. $3,000,000 is authorized for fiscal years 2013-2015. The Director of the Office of Entrepreneurial Education is required to submit a report on best practices of entrepreneurial education and training programs within 180 days of the enactment of the Act. The report will be sent to the Senate and House Committees on Small Business and Entrepreneurship. The report, to be submitted by the Director of the Office of Entrepreneurial Education, will include a description of exemplary programs at national, regional, state, and local levels, as well as a summary of entrepreneurial education programs by the Federal Government, state and local governments, nonprofit organizations, and private sector groups. SEC. 4. MASTER OF BUSINESS ADMINISTRATION SCHOLARSHIP PILOT PROGRAM. The Administrator may award up to 100 scholarships of $1,500 each to MBA students on a competitive basis. Recipients must provide free assistance to small businesses for 1-2 weeks. At least 50% of recipients must be students at higher education institutions. The Administrator must ensure that at least 50% of scholarship recipients are students at institutions with limited entrepreneurship opportunities. Activities must support various small business and entrepreneurial projects, and each student must have a mentor. The scholarship recipients must engage in interdisciplinary and multi-institutional projects, with each student having a mentor to guide them. Data collection is required from both students and small business concerns or entrepreneurs who receive assistance. Non-compliance with the agreement may result in consequences for the student. The agreement requires scholarship recipients to provide information on assistance use, employment status, and compliance for 3 years after graduation. Failure to comply results in the scholarship being treated as a loan subject to repayment with interest. Authorization of appropriations is provided for this program. The Administrator may award scholarships with specified terms and conditions until September 30, 2015. $200,000 is authorized for each fiscal year 2013-2015. SEC. 5. REGIONAL ENTREPRENEURIAL COMPETITIONS. The Administrator will establish a program for regional competitions and a national conference to address challenges through entrepreneurial research and business planning. Regional offices will identify issues, sponsor competitions for small businesses, and collaborate with universities. The Administrator will establish a program for regional competitions and a national conference to address challenges through entrepreneurial research and business planning. Entrepreneurs submit research and business plans to address identified issues, outreach is provided to universities and business communities to promote the competition, and the best plans are selected for submission to the Administrator. The Administrator will organize a national conference for selected research and business plans from regional competitions. A panel of 11 employees will choose the best plans for submission. The Administrator will designate 11 employees to select the best research and business plans from regional competitions for submission. The Administrator will award a $50,000 grant to selected plans and recipients must submit a report on grant usage within a year. $750,000 is authorized for the Administrator to carry out this section. The Administrator, in consultation with the Secretary of Education, must submit a report to Congress within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The report will include recommendations for legislation to forgive and defer student loans to support youth entrepreneurship by providing capital for business formation.
